The Migration of Chinese Churches to Taiwan  


In 1949, as the Chinese Civil War turned unfavorable for the Kuomintang (KMT) government led by Chiang Kai-shek, the Republic of China (ROC) began retreating to Taiwan. On October 1, 1949, under the leadership of Mao Zedong, the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) declared victory and established the People's Republic of China (PRC). In its first year of rule, the CCPâ€™s atheist policies forced thousands of foreign missionaries to leave China.  


Since the 19th century, various Christian missionary organizations from Europe and the United States had been active in China. With the political shift in 1949, many of these missions relocated to Taiwan. These included theBaptist Church, Methodist Church, Lutheran Church, Quaker Church, Christian Missionary Alliance, Assemblies of God, Episcopal Church, Holiness Church, Evangelical Fellowship, Church of the Nazarene, Zion Church, Christian and Missionary Alliance, Church of the Nazarene, Sabbath Church, Mennonite Church, Bread of Life Church, Lutheran Church, China Evangelistic Mission, and the Local Church (å¬æœƒ), among others. This migration contributed to Taiwanâ€™s present-day landscape of diverse Christian denominations.  


As these new religious groups arrived in Taiwan, they found a receptive environment. Many of the new immigrants who had followed the KMT to Taiwan were displaced from their homeland, experiencing uncertainty and seeking spiritual solace. The well-resourced missionaries and churches that had relocated from mainland China actively recruited members in densely populated areas and schools. Consequently, Christian churches began emerging rapidly across Taiwan.  


Another significant factor in the expansion of Christianity in Taiwan during this period was the personal faith ofChiang Kai-shek and Soong Mei-ling, which held considerable influence in the authoritarian era. This relationship between the ruling elite and the church led to deep ties between the Christian community and the government, extending beyond political and military control. *(Huang Kexian, 2021, 72-73)*  


Additionally, the denominations that relocated to Taiwan came from different missionary regions in China, resulting in variations within the same denominational traditions. This historical divergence continues to shape the landscape of Christianity in Taiwan today. Furthermore, the Christian groups that arrived in 1949 often held different political and theological positions from thePresbyterian Church in Taiwan, which had been established for over a century. These differences led to tensions that persist in Taiwan's Christian community to this day.

 The Communist Party of China (CPC)


The Communist Party of China (CPC) is currently the ruling party of the People's Republic of China. It was founded by Chen Duxiu and Li Dazhao in August 1920, during the Beiyang Government period of the Republic of China. In 1922, the CPC joined the Communist International (Comintern), receiving its guidance and support. Subsequently, it cooperated with the Kuomintang (KMT) in the Northern Expedition, successfully dismantling the Beiyang warlords and the Beiyang Government. However, after the first KMT-CPC cooperation collapsed in 1927, the two parties engaged in a decade-long military struggle.


From the 1930s onward, a domestic faction led by Mao Zedong emerged, allowing the CPC to gradually break away from the influence of the Comintern. In 1931, the party established the "Chinese Soviet Republic," the first Soviet-style regime in China led by the CPC, advocating the overthrow of the Nationalist Government and the KMT. 


During the Second Sino-Japanese War, the CPC and the KMT formed a second cooperative alliance, establishing a united front against Japanese aggression. However, after Japanâ€™s surrender in 1945, the CPC organized and led the People's Liberation Army, ultimately defeating the KMT and the National Revolutionary Army in the second phase of the Chinese Civil War. The CPC then secured control over mainland China and most coastal islands. In 1949, it established the People's Republic of China (PRC), becoming the de facto ruling party, a position it has maintained to the present day.


 The CPCâ€™s Religious Policies and Christian Churches in China


As an atheist Leninist party, the CPC has exercised control over religious activities, including Christian churches. Before the founding of the PRC in 1949, many foreign missionaries voluntarily left their mission areas in anticipation of impending changes. After 1949, foreign clergy were either forced to leave mainland China, followed the KMT government to Taiwan, relocated to British Hong Kong, or returned to their home countries.


Although the Constitution of the People's Republic of China contains provisions guaranteeing religious freedom, their actual implementation has been subject to debate. Under the guidance of then-Premier Zhou Enlai, the government proposed the "Three-Self" principlesâ€”self-governance, self-support, and self-propagation. In July 1950, Christian leaders, including Wu Yaozong, jointly issued the "Three-Self Declaration," launching the Three-Self Patriotic Movement in response to the government's call for churches to operate independently from foreign influence (Xing Fuzeng, 2020, p. 105).


In terms of Protestant Christianity, the first National Christian Conference was held in Beijing in 1954, formally establishing the Three-Self Patriotic Movement Committee of Protestant Churches in China. Later, the China Christian Council was also established, and together they are collectively referred to as the "National Two Christian Organizations." Protestant churches in China are required to join the state-sanctioned "Three-Self Church," operate under CPC leadership, and accept supervision and regulation by the State Administration for Religious Affairs. Today, the Three-Self Patriotic Movement Church is the largest Christian organization in mainland China.

Shinto Shrine Worship

After the Meiji Restoration, Japan promoted the nationalization of Shinto as a state religion, leading to the establishment of shrines throughout the country. These newly established shrines symbolized state power and served as a means to transmit national consciousness to local populations, with the ultimate goal of transforming society into loyal subjects of the emperor (Murakami Shigeyoshi, 1982, pp. 5-6). Shinto shrines became emblematic of Japanese imperialism, regarded as part of colonial governance through religion. As Japan expanded its colonial empire during World War II, shrines were established across its colonies, gradually integrating into the daily lives of colonial residents (Tsai Jin-tang, 1994, pp. 15-19). In newly developed territories such as Hokkaido and colonies like Taiwan and Korea, colonial subjects were often forced to participate in shrine customs and rituals during the war period.

The Japanese colonial government saw the swift "Japanization" of Taiwan as essential for governance, aiming to reshape Taiwanese identity into that of a nation centered on the emperor's sovereignty. From 1895 to 1945, with the full support of the Japanese colonial administration, shrines dedicated to Shinto deities symbolizing absolute authority were constructed across towns and villages in Taiwan. By the end of the Naichi EnchÅ (Inner Territory Extension) policy in ShÅwa 9 (1934), the government sought to achieve the goal of "one shrine per town or village" (Taiwan Governor-General's Bureau of Education and Social Affairs, 1943).

In 1900, the Japanese House of Representatives passed a resolution on the "Proposal for the Construction of a Special Official Shrine in Taiwan." Simultaneously, the Ministry of Home Affairs announced, in Notification No. 81, the decision to establish Taiwan Shrine (Tsai Jin-tang, 1994, pp. 15-19). This shrine was built to commemorate Prince Kitashirakawa Yoshihisa, who led the Imperial Guard Expeditionary Force that landed at Aodi on May 31, 1895. The force engaged in battles from Keelung to Tainan, where the prince eventually succumbed to illness. He was later honored as the "Guardian of Taiwan." As the first official shrine in an overseas colony, Taiwan Shrine designated October 28â€”the day of the princeâ€™s passingâ€”as its annual festival day. The Governor-General declared this day a public holiday across the island, during which an imperial envoy and the Governor-General, accompanied by government and military officials as well as local elites, would participate in worship ceremonies, demonstrating the shrineâ€™s supreme political and symbolic significance (Tsai Jin-tang, 1994, p. 23).

In 1936, the Taiwan Governor-Generalâ€™s Office launched the Kominka (imperialization) movement, introducing the "Ethical Reform Movement," which promoted reverence for gods and ancestors, the veneration of imperial ancestors, and the widespread adoption of the national language (Japanese) among Taiwanese people. As part of this initiative, Taiwanese were required to use Japanese in daily life and were encouraged to participate in shrine worship and the veneration of sacred Shinto amulets (Taima hÅsai) (Tsai Jin-tang, 1991, pp. 69-72). By the final phase of the war, during the "Imperial Citizens Service Movement," efforts were intensified to fully instill Japanese imperial ideology, leading to the establishment of various patriotic service organizations (Hsu Chien-hsin, 1965, pp. 262-264).

During this period, Christian missionary schoolsâ€”particularly middle schoolsâ€”faced severe challenges. Schools such as Chang Jung High School and Tamkang High School struggled with the requirement of "shrine worship," which became a condition for government recognition. Initially, church leaders strongly resisted, but they were eventually forced to comply with the Japanese Ministry of Educationâ€™s argument that shrine worship was a "supra-religious" patriotic act. The Kominka movement posed significant dilemmas for missionary schools, not only altering curricula and school administration but also striking at the core of their religious identity through the demand for shrine worship (Lo Chi-ming, 2016, pp. 24-25).

The February 28 Incident

The February 28 Incident refers to the violent conflicts between the government and civilians that erupted across Taiwan from February 27 to May 16, 1947. The Taiwanese people demanded political reform, but the Nationalist Government of the Republic of China ultimately dispatched military forces to suppress the uprising with brutal force.

After World War II, the people of Taiwan eagerly anticipated the islandâ€™s reintegration into China. Some figures from the Presbyterian Church, such as Tsai Pei-huo and Chen Si-zhi, even composed songs to celebrate Taiwanâ€™s "liberation" (Chen Guan-zhou, 2002, p. 35). However, the incoming Chinese administration treated Taiwan as a new colonial possession rather than as a reclaimed territory, subjecting the island's people to even greater suffering.

Many Taiwanese civil servants who had been employed under the Japanese administration were dismissed en masse, while those who remained were often subjected to discrimination and humiliation by their Chinese colleagues (Chang Yan-xian et al., 2006, pp. 13-42, 171-221). The lived experiences, language, and education that Taiwanese had acquired under Japanese rule were not recognized; instead, they were denigrated as remnants of Japanese imperialism (Lai Ze-han, 1994, pp. 3-27). Economically, Taiwan suffered from severe hyperinflation due to the Nationalist government's planned economy policies. Rising unemployment, food shortages, and widespread economic hardship led to a series of social crises (Chang Yan-xian et al., 2006, pp. 13-42). Additionally, infighting among different factions of the Kuomintang (KMT) further weakened political and military discipline, leading to rampant corruption (Lai Ze-han, 1994, pp. 3-27). These accumulated grievances set the stage for the February 28 Incident, triggered by an event on February 27, 1947. On that day, Monopoly Bureau agents attempted to crack down on illegal cigarette sales near Tianma Teahouse in Taipeiâ€™s Taipingding district. During the raid, they severely injured a cigarette vendor, Lin Jiang-mai, and accidentally shot and killed a bystander, Chen Wen-xi. This incident quickly escalated, igniting island-wide unrest within days (Lai Ze-han, 1994, pp. 47-81).

In an attempt to mediate the crisis and address public grievances, representatives from various counties and cities, along with local gentry, formed the February 28 Incident Settlement Committee. They hoped to resolve the conflict through political negotiations and proposed political reforms (Lai Ze-han, 1994, pp. 47-81).

At first, Governor-General Chen Yi appeared to compromise, accepting the committeeâ€™s recommendations. However, he secretly regarded the uprising as an act of "rebellion." Soon after, the central government deployed troops to Taiwan to carry out large-scale purges. This military crackdown resulted in the mass arrest, execution, or disappearance of numerous Taiwanese, including many intellectuals and elites who had no direct involvement in the protests (Chang Yan-xian et al., 2006, pp. 43-76, 171-243, 449-489).

Among the victims were several prominent members of the Presbyterian Church, including Pastor Xiao Chao-jin (leader of the Three Principles of the People Youth League); Zhang Qi-lang, a renowned doctor from Fenglin (who was also a delegate to the Constitutional National Assembly, speaker of the Hualien County Council, and a physician), along with his two sons; Taipei City Councilor Xu Chun-qing; Dr. Lin Mao-sheng, acting dean of the College of Liberal Arts at National Taiwan University; Chen Neng-tong, principal of Tamkang High School; discipline director Huang A-tong; teacher Lu Yuan; chairman Xu Chun-qing; Kaohsiung City Councilors Xu Qiu-zong and Tu Guang-ming; lawyers and brothers Li Rui-han and Li Rui-feng; and Ruan Chao-ri, president of the Taiwan Shin Sheng Daily News, among many others (Li Xin-ren, 2011).
